sound • text • multimedia

floating world variations

floating world variations


inspired by japanese 浮世 [“the floating world”] prints

each layer stencilled
in what could be seventeen
superimpositions

of

imprinted figures
fleshed by what the mind makes up:
i know—i had one

once

—a city clouded
with crowds, flocks of markings etched
in paper, gazing

at

impressions of sky
implying a place between
there and everywhere,

where

people could be both:
ideal perspectives of
ordinary scenes,

because

they are made for you
and of you, for you to see
yourself reflected

like

your face in the mirror,
layered by each returning,
yet still just as flat:

after

all the prints you’ve bought
to fill yourself with yourself,
the art is reduced

to

mere appearance: why
i believe my images,
but not my belief:

for

this print isn’t mine;
it’s foreign; that is, not some
thing i’ve really seen:

just

something that i dreamed
and stuck between wall and air
to keep me comfort—

but

when i woke, it had
already fallen: perhaps
weighted by paper

or

brushed by me asleep;
so i stared at the hangings
before turning away,

always

going forward: find
some other dream, other theme,
as if the whole point

is

keeping it floating
—perhaps that’s why i resist
anything defined,

as

future flutters me,
ream of self-seeking portraits
keeping layers aligned

in

language’s flatness:
if you ask for something deep,
i’ll just write a poem.

chopin


for fryderyk chopin

   into the room,
you coughed shadow:
 
  bent over reverberant bones
    & coaxed ripples
in the mirage’s dark gauze,
the heavy hanging drapes
  dappled:

  they call it mystery—but we

   who are scattered
 around your smoke,
    the charcoal dance
 (which is all we have left of your figure)

are asking, without the words, what
     it is like to be underwater—but you are sound,

   now, & the fabric
twists, damped by the moisture your melody echoes.
    & i am drenched in rust:

is there really
no way of saying you?

they have tried, with charcoal voices.
  most have become your motion
 (& it echoes backwards,
   back towards black & white)—& one

has made a place
and implied you.

  but why are we still here?
 because of steam,
because the friction of waves shades feeling:
 
as splintered echoes glint off
strings, we are shards of singing. we wish
we had been there.

you were grey,
   and danced.

dance


after joan mitchell’s “café”

  what a storm is on the wall—
    an object of streaks, a tangle
  of soul,
of yellows, reds, that iridescent halo exploring
the limits of its frame,

and that almost black blue
 shock
  as if a figure at its center,
      swathed all these colors, as if
    trying to be everything at once

   so much so that the dance cuts its figure
    and “bleeds”

—as my pen scratches
          unable to escape reference
   to these paint swatches plastered to the canvas

 (though Mitchell believed reference profane: instead
      trying
   to “define a feeling”)—

  my burning blue flesh, with
no way of putting paint to paper,
and instead this art
of spasms rasping philosophical

at the ethereal blue, the halo
  feinting back the central swatch
  from the canvas’ corners,
    a glow from the edges, a realness of mist
  mystifying, as if the evidence
      that this figure is paint, meeting paint again—

snow travellers


after cézanne’s “snow at argenteuil”

he made us 
            barren, buried by a soggy fog
of blended yellow and blue
            until we were wet linen
      greased with the weight of paint,

     figures on a ground
           of grey gradient
        fading away
until it creases 
back into above,
      that fabric of frozen gust
that blows us to stains of thick pigment 
 on canvas,
         spread into tranquil storm:
 
  and we are just two
  blotches among others
          in a cluster

                   to be traced,
blurred, brushed
    
 by the light’s feathered knife, 
          like a wing swooping towards sight:
it slices, blemishes, breezes, and leaves

               us, visited by its ricochet:
         passengers on flatness
         brushed into being
          by the bristles’ furtive murmur,
textures on sheen—

rainstick



as again, snow falls cotton on the roof, i cough,
knuckles white around the white plastic
of the zoloft bottle, like a rainstick 
 silent
since the dry season:
   the dust-clutch
      in stomach, the gulp
    of synthesized serotonin swallowed whole—

i rattle the bottle’s hollow clatter:
the dead-grass rasp
of my clammy tongue clouded
 by the past’s clasp,

the clinched it 
as fingers find the outer grooves, childproof,
to rub the echoing whole

 and roll it around again
     (for would one repeat the refilling and respilling
    again, and then again):
                  this plastic rainstick
      recycling a cluster of dead clicks
      to keep the fibers alive and writhing,
          and writing
      words whose ring clings to circular surface,
                                 calling—

happiness


after “happiness” by robert hass

because when i rubbed blear from my eyes 
corkscrew-like to get the sleep-flakes out
             and looked across the room hung with halflit dust
                 there was 
a shadow at my window
   —perhaps of a bird or a half-broke branch
 or one of those flecks in my sight
(anyways nothing to be made sentient,
               just the rorschachs of waking)

and because that hum hasn’t stopped since i can remember,
 only modulates its pitch as if some 
 unpredictable vibrato
     drilling into my monologue
    (and when you would drift in we’d talk about transistors and translation,
as if machines shock silicone toward meaning
          with very specific shades of light, 
and the mind is a machine for making machines,
 a sentience shocking its objects)

and because i read this poem saying ‘symbolize’ twice
  behind flecks on a screen with pixels so small
   that one can only see their meaning
  (and isn’t the speaker’s tension one of
 bristling or multiplicity, as the shadow
 shakes behind imagery)

and because the page is flecked with erasing
  and anyway all this short-circuits my insight

i wrote: happiness…and distracted pulled up your picture
at 19, pressing your head to my shoulder, humming
in my ear, and staring at me through the screen.

Silver Cove



We visited him again for the first time 
in eons, it seemed,
to reenact a three-tiered silhouette 
 projected against the beach:

it was sky shocked open, as we left my dark room
    to round curves of coast,
     pass around slower drivers:

my father and I drove into questions of time:
 when did you lose yourself
 when you were me

 —in some capacity—
as if the paths were aligned in time, corresponding
  to some rough symmetry
(for I will have had me soon, if I was you)
 —and if you were me, what would you do
    with the years after graduation, as if falling 
       off some dark
  cliff—

 and I tell the dog to come down from there
 “I don’t want you to fall”
 and father sits back, watching
  until he finds the half-falling way
 and grandpa looks back and says
  “I have so much work to do:”

 and he can’t walk so we watch
the breaks in waves pounding stones to multiplicity—
 remembering how he left his son who now wishes me
 to continue my “legacy”

    into what—the way I’d codify
these impressions into something to impress,
      to pass
on—to progeny or “audience,” this raw consciousness
                    pressing its advice into new forms

 —and grandpa says become an expert 
in something,
because it’s all been lateral, and now
        the experts said they’ll put him under for an operation
so he leaves us with three forms to fill out,
 and the image of us three smiling
with me in between,
 
our eyes squeezed between sun and the same uncomprehending flame,
the same aging realization,

      that in figuring eternity, everything 
      is passed down incomplete;

that I will return 
wishing for more of his language
      I always thought myself too young to understand.
